unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about managing cash flow, especially with online banking these days. Thought I'd share my experience, being a small business owner in Mumbai.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about managing cash flow, especially with online banking these days. Thought I'd share my experience, being a small business owner in Mumbai.

unnormalised: Early on, I used to handle everything with wads of ₹500 notes, literally. Dealing with suppliers meant trips to the bank to withdraw Rs. 20000 at a time, then counting it all out. It was so time-consuming and honestly, pretty risky. I remember once, back in '18, almost losing Rs 5000 near Dadar station. Scary stuff!
normalised: Early on, I used to handle everything with wads of rupee five hundred notes, literally. Dealing with suppliers meant trips to the bank to withdraw rupees twenty thousand at a time, then counting it all out. It was so time-consuming and honestly, pretty risky. I remember once, back in two thousand eighteen, almost losing rupees five thousand near Dadar station. Scary stuff!

unnormalised: Then came UPI and net banking. Game changer! Now, I pay most suppliers directly through the bank. Transactions happen in seconds. For example, I recently transferred Rs. 15500 to a supplier in Delhi via NEFT. The bank charged me, like, ₹5 as a transaction fee, which is nothing compared to the hassle I used to go through.
normalised: Then came U-P-I and net banking. Game changer! Now, I pay most suppliers directly through the bank. Transactions happen in seconds. For example, I recently transferred rupees fifteen thousand five hundred to a supplier in Delhi via N-E-F-T. The bank charged me, like, rupee five as a transaction fee, which is nothing compared to the hassle I used to go through.

unnormalised: But cash is still king for some things. My auto-rickshaw driver only accepts cash (Rs 300 for a ride across town!), and the local tea stall guy definitely isn't swiping cards. Plus, you need cash for tips, small purchases, and emergencies, right? So, I still withdraw, say, Rs 3000 every month for these expenses. I try to limit my cash usage to a max of Rs 500 a day.
normalised: But cash is still king for some things. My auto-rickshaw driver only accepts cash (rupees three hundred for a ride across town!), and the local tea stall guy definitely isn't swiping cards. Plus, you need cash for tips, small purchases, and emergencies, right? So, I still withdraw, say, rupees three thousand every month for these expenses. I try to limit my cash usage to a maximum of rupees five hundred a day.

unnormalised: The trick is balance. Online banking is amazing, but you gotta keep some cash handy. Track your spending religiously, and don't forget to reconcile your bank statements every month. Keeps things transparent and prevents any nasty surprises! Hope that helps.
normalised: The trick is balance. Online banking is amazing, but you gotta keep some cash handy. Track your spending religiously, and don't forget to reconcile your bank statements every month. Keeps things transparent and prevents any nasty surprises! Hope that helps.
